title: Are games nowadays too short?
body:
Hello all, I was wondering if I could ask your opinions on something...

I've been playing casually on and off since Season 5, and have noticed one thing in particular, especially during this season: games seem to be incredibly short nowadays. 
From my experience, matches seem to only last 20-25 minutes at most, and can even end around the 15-18 minute mark! 
This seems to be quite an issue, as entire matches seem to be decided within the first few minutes, and it is incredibly easy for one team to snowball a lead out of control. Match this with paper mâché towers stuffed with first blood gold, and it is incredibly difficult to mount a comeback, not to mention usually quite unenjoyable to attempt to play from behind, as in all likeliness there will be very little chance for your team to achieve victory, unless of course all of the enemy team dced consecutively for a good 10 minutes. 

Has anyone else been finding this an issue? I am by no means the most experienced player, as though I have been around since mid Season 5, I have been playing very inconsistently since then due to a myriad of reasons, however even as the low elo scrub that I am, I feel that this is quite a balancing flaw currently. I wanted to ask everyone else's opinion on the matter, and see if we can get a discussion going about this, since I do see it as an issue currently (maybe others will disagree, but I find is somewhat broken). 

What suggestions would you propose to fix this issue? Buffing towers? Nerfing Rift Herald and first blood tower gold? Let me know below, if you would care to.

replies.body:
The length is fine

It's the snowball affect that is bad or feels too quick
^ This along with the fact that nearly every soloQ teammate I get wants to surrender and give up after a bad early.

Oftentimes, the feeling that games are too snowbally is actually misdiagnosed as: won games are drawn out for too long. If the game is decided at 10 minutes, forcing players to stick around for the entire time is probably bad. 

On the flip side, your experience of games feeling like they are over, when they actually aren't may be misdiagnosed as "comeback mechanics are not clear". We do a reasonable job of displaying bounties and other rubber banding mechanics for gold, but not for XP.

Well... If you put your game in a state where games CAN be decided in 10 minutes... while the whole map and structure and objective system is made for way longer games... maybe THERE the flaw can be found.

Not in the fact that those decided game last for another 15 minutes since it simply takes time to break through to the base no matter how much Turret-HATE you throw into the game. xD

Games are more tense when they're shorter, not longer.  The shorter a game is, the more each individual play matters. Who cares about losing a small skirmish at 5 minutes if the game takes 50 minutes to end anyway? That's how I felt during all of season 5. Pick Vayne/GP/Veigar/Sej/etc, fuck early game, stall for late every single goddamn game.

>A game where it's possible to win 3v5?
Shit wasn't Balanced and individual skill held alot more weight to the game back in the day

You're still describing bronze. If it's possible for a team to win 3v5, then either the enemy is complete shit (aka bronze) or it's possible for the 3 to snowball so hard that they can actually win against 5. Weren't we just complaining about games being too snowbally?

>And Yet One of the biggest complaints from the community is most games are one sided stomps

Most people have no idea how to play once they're behind and continue to dig their hole deeper and deeper. I fail to see why Riot should bail those people out; comebacks still happen all the fucking time if you do the right things.

>I have been around from the dawn of the game. Hour long games were long yet normal back in the day.

As have I. Hour long games were great if you were the losing team making a comeback. **_But hour long games sucked if you were the winning team and couldn't finish out a game_**.

Now I'm not saying "couldn't finish out a game" as in "lol our team just goofing around cuz we so far ahead xD lol we just died oh well xD oh noes they are getting gold and catching up, and our cockiness is making us not take them seriously anymore when we should". Rather, I am saying that you couldn't finish out a game back then because the game simply didn't reward your good playstyle and good in-game choices enough.

And this argument will apply even to today's state of the game: if my team plays a flawless early game, even if we don't have early-game champions, why should we lose/why should the enemy team be able to stall out the game and **_NEGATE_** all of our good plays and choices, just on the merit of a passive, non-interactive playstyle? 

The Gameplay Boards has been up in arms about the non-interactive playstyle of Ancient Coin item line, and how Ancient Coin users earn more gold than Relic Shield and Spell Thief users, but without entertaining significant risks for that gold. While the game may reward non-interaction in the Ancient Coin line, that playstyle has been dropped in so many other facets of the game.

I know there's an argument to be made for lategame scaling champs, and I think that's a valid argument. However, the style of the game has changed in the last few years, in such a way that good early game choices are not negated by non-interactive playstyles on a MACRO level. And I enjoy that. I like being rewarded for playing well and making good choices, and being offered options to take my lead to close out a game. Sure, I don't get to stall out the game when I'm losing much anymore, but that's part of the game being fair, as I wouldn't want my enemies to be able to do that. 

_**Nothing says "fuck you for being better at the game" like allowing non-interactive macro-level play to stifle any rewards for playing well. **_
Quite the post.  I agree for the most part

yeah, it'd be nice if (other than first blood) the gold from champ kills don't really come online until the 10 min mark. like kills before 10min start at 100g and grow to be worth 200g by 10min and come fully online at 15min for their full value of 300g.

at least this way, it'd help teams focus on farming minions instead of playing stupid trying to get fed off kills.

But why though? If I put in the effort into killing my opponent early, shouldn't they be punished? Shouldn't I be rewarded for getting that kill through my effort? Why are we actively rewarding passive playstyles over aggressive?

they are punished. they lose out on cs and, most crucially, exp. the giant gold lead on top of that is just overly punishing, and (against skilled players) basically wins the lane from just 1 kill. The only way the lane can be turned around is with several successful ganks from the jungler. and that will leave the rest of the map vulnerable while the jungler has to baby sit the lane if he wants it to win

100 gold for an early kill outside first blood is comparable to 4-5 CS. One kill doesn't snowball the lane, making the same mistakes that an enemy exploits does. I see it all the time down bot, and mid. Yes, this comment is akin to saying "Git gud", but people need to learn how to adjust to an ahead opponent, instead of running their head through the brick wall.

understood, and I agree to an extent, but that change does not, and will not, happen in just one game. It's something that will take many games for said player to slowly learn. _If_ they learn it at all. The problem is that for all the games that the player _doesn't_ learn this is causing frustration for 4 other players who now have to sit thru yet another game with a fed opponent that's godlike by the 10 min mark and are just praying the 20 min mark comes fast enough for a surrender.

Also, I've played many games where even if my lane opponent gets  even 1 lucky kill early, they're the ones that become super aggressive, and I'm forced to play extremely defensively and ultimately end up losing the lane since my opponent is nigh unkillable while still dishing out tons of damage.

No clue why you were downvoted, I think that’s a valid idea. 
Kills are make-or-break early on, so if they meant less earlier on, it would make for a much for enjoyable game. 

As opposed to focusing on farming, I believe the early game should be used to find out who you’re versing. Whether they’re timid, or aggressive players, etc. This is best achieved if kills weren’t so heavy early on.

It's not just feeling like the game is decided by decisions earlier, *it's actually ending sooner*. I've had games end in less than 20 minutes, even without surrenders. That should never happen in League!

> [{quoted}](name=DrCyanide,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=N50jgzuK,comment-id=00090007,timestamp=2017-10-10T02:36:37.694+0000)

Why not? Seriously why not? If 1 team dominates the early game so hard that they can end before 20 minutes, why on earth would you want to drag that out longer?

I'm not oppose to a MOBA ending before 20 minutes, it's even an extremely desirable part of mobile MOBAs. I doubt I'd be opposed to League being shortened to consistently be that long if it felt like it was by design.

My problem is that these games don't feel like they're balanced out designed to play that way. They're such extreme one sided stomps that when they happen I'm left wondering about the state of Matchmaking and the game as a whole.

If you wanted 20 minutes to be average League game length, why have 6 item slots? 3 or 4 would be plenty with the current gold gen model. Why have 11 towers per team when they primarily stall out games with sieges? Why have inhibitors respawn? Why not have Rift Herald respawn? Why have an objective that only spawns after 35 minutes?

League's current design speaks to an intent for a longer game time than 20 minutes. That's why when I'd get these 18 minute games in Silver (you know, that place where no one knows how to close out a game) it really worries me. It indicates that the underlying principles the game was built on are falling apart.

Or often it's just that there's a lack of any comeback mechanics and games do end too quickly for any comeback to be possible. It's not that these mechanics are unclear, it's that they don't exist. A team that snowballs has already won assuming they have any idea what to do with their lead because towers are completely and utterly indefensible.
Bounty gold and catch-up exp aren't comeback mechanics?

Please revert the bounty gold change

The length of games also depends on how skilled the players are?

The issue right now is that their is no middle-ground. Take {{champion:238}} for example. The original win condition goes like this:

* **Early:** Win lane
* **Early-Mid:** Roam
* **Mid-Late:** Splitpush
* **Late:** Splitpush, Catch & Cleanup

Taking Herald  is suddenly mandatory to finish it in the midgame. So the stakes are very high.

---

Now let's watch what lcs does:

* They take scaling champions
* They are not going for the early game, they are going for the midgame
* Herald is just a bonus (yet gives them an extreemly edge when used well)

It's really clear to see {{item:3504}} + {{champion:18}} for example is a really midgame monster. She's spiking way to early, yet has the monsterious lategame security as well. This is what wrong with league right now:

* **Earlygame Team Comps:** Their is not enouge options if it does go lategame (splitpushing, catching, etc)
* **Midgame Team Comps:** This group seems the only group that is fine right now. Maybe champions are partly shifted into this group to supposely fix them. Yet this group is rather broken as well. Especially the ones with siege.
* **Lategame Team Comps:** They spike way to early, almost make them a midgame champion

---

The fixes are rather simple:

* Buff up splitpush/catch options so early champions can compeet in the lategame.
* Slightly nerfs the midgame of lategame champions again or nerf their lategame to compensate for their stronger midgame.
* Buff or introduce new support items that can compeet with {{item:3504}} that can push the meta in different directions.

The current problem with the game is that by 10 minutes you can tell who will win but by 15 minutes there could be enough question that people wont FF because "They could throw" and yes they could but most likely wont.

This is in part because the first 10m is sooo unforgiving.

A top or mid lane could be evenly matched and someone makes ONE small mistake and die and that lane is now FULLY lost.
The advantage the winner gets from a early kill or even a early forced back is too much.  THe Snowball is now rolling and now the FULL team has to play very well to offset that snowball.  If your team is not understanding of the WHOLE map its lost.  There is no winning that match most likely. 

This should not be.  The game should not be set in the first 10 minutes.  By 20 minutes should be a hmm it looks like X side is ahead, at 30 minutes is where it should be at the current 10 minute mark.

The game should not be COMPLETELY lost because of player is bad (shows how messed up the MMR system is).

Even as an ADC main I really dislike the game length.

Half of my games are over at 20-25 minutes. Even if I snowballed and am doing really well, I barely get to feel my power before we close out a game.
Its because the matchmaking creates such unbalanced teams. Often the W or L is determined by Riot before the game even starts, at least at the lower ELOs
